abstract.t: This document describes a CBOR tag for providing type information to CBOR data. Unlike the native CBOR tagging scheme which builds on integers in a IANA registry, this specification supports text based type identifiers. This eables type identifiers to be expressed as URLs, potentially pointing to web pages holding related descriptions in human readable form, as well as being compatible with established methods for adding type information to JSON and XML data.

section.name: Introduction
section.t: This specification introduces a method for augmenting data expressed in the CBOR notation, with a text based type identifier mechanism.

The primary purpose is to enable developers defining application specific type identifiers without nessesarily having to go through an external registration process. Using URLs
should due to their ubiquity be a candidate for CBOR based applications. See also .

This specification is also intended to provide a path for ISO using CBOR as a possible alternative to XML by supporting their current URN
based identifier naming scheme. See also .
By applying the typing scheme to top level data items, additional functionality is enabled including:

ul.li: Support for embedding in other CBOR and non-CBOR constructs, as well as storage in databases without any additional information.
Remove the need for application specific media types. In many cases "application/cbor" should suffice.

section.name: Terminology
section.t: In this document the term CBOR "object" is used interchangeably with the CBOR "data item".

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", " SHALL NOT ", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCPÂ 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.name: Specification
section.t: This specification builds on the CBOR tag feature (major type 6), by defining a fixed tag with the preliminary decimal value of 1010. See also .

This tag MUST in turn enclose a CBOR array with two elements, where the first element is assumed to contain an object type identifier in textual format, while the second element holds the object (instance) data itself. The type identifier MUST be a valid CBOR text string (major type 3), while the object itself MUST be a valid but arbitrary CBOR object.
The syntax expressed in CBOR diagnostic notation (section 8 of ) would read as:
1010([Object Identifier, Object Data])
Note that real-world usages will typically impose constraints like requiring object identifiers to be expressed as HTTPS URLs etc.

section.name: Sample
section.t: Consider the following sample:
Converting the sample above to CBOR expressed in hexadecimal notation (here shown with embedded comments as well), should result in the following output:
section.sourcecode: D9 03F2 # tag(1010) 82 # array(2) 78 1C # text(28) 68747470733A2F2F6578616D706C652E636F6D2F6D796F626A656374 # "https://example.com/myobject" A2 # map(2) 01 # unsigned(1) 64 # text(4) 64617461 # "data" 02 # unsigned(2) 69 # text(9) 6D6F72652064617461 # "more data"
section.t: In a typical implementation "https://example.com/myobject" would also serve as a hyper-link to human readable information about the identifier, accessed through a Web browser.

section.name: Security Considerations
section.t: This specification inherits all the security considerations of CBOR .

URL-based type identifiers MUST NOT be used for automatically downloading CBOR schema data like CDDL
to CBOR processors, since this introduces potential vulnerabilities.
The availability of type information does in no way limit the need for input data validation.
For signed CBOR objects, it is RECOMMENDED to include the type identifier extension in the signature calculation as well. The same considerations apply to encryption using AEAD algorithms.

section.name: URI and URL Identifiers
section.t:
The primary reason for using URI or URL
based identifiers is for maintaining a single name-space for the entire specification of a system. Note that the referenced URL specification does not distinguish between URIs and URLs.
This non-normative section describes different methods for dealing with identifiers expressed as URIs or URLs.

section.name: Registering a Dedicated Domain
section.t: A core issue with identifiers depending on domain (DNS) names is that domain names may not necessarily remain valid during the anticipated life time of an identifier. The owner of a domain name may due to organizational changes, neglect, lack of interest, or even death, lose control over its use, effectively leaving associated identifiers orphaned.

section.name: Using a Sub-domain
section.t: An alternative is using a dedicated sub-domain belonging to an entity that is likely to survive for the forseeable future. With the advent of public repositories like GitHub, this appears to be a simpler, cheaper, and more robust solution than maintaining dedicated domain names.

section.name: The 'tag' URI Scheme
section.t:
For applications where strict control over the name-space is hard to achieve, the 'tag' URI scheme
may be used.

section.name: URN Identifiers
section.t: ISO currently use URN based identifiers like "urn:iso:std:iso:20022:tech:xsd:pain.001.001.10" for data definitions using XML schema . This method could be applied to CBOR and CDDL as well.
